summary: This is a court order by Judge Alison J. Nathan denying Ghislaine Maxwell's request to stop flashlight checks at the MDC, but urging the MDC to consider reducing sleep disruptions for pretrial detainees and to ensure Maxwell is only subjected to necessary security protocols. The order addresses defense claims that frequent flashlight checks are disrupting Maxwell's sleep and ability to prepare for trial.

events.title: Defense Request on Sleeping Conditions
events.description: Defense counsel for Ghislaine Maxwell wrote to the court requesting it address her sleeping conditions, claiming guards shine a flashlight in her eyes every 15 minutes at night, disrupting her sleep and trial preparation.

events.title: Court Order on Flashlight Checks
events.description: Judge Nathan denied Maxwell's request to stop flashlight checks as factually unsubstantiated and legally unsupported, but urged the MDC to consider reducing sleep disruptions and ensure only necessary security protocols are applied.

locations: MDC (Metropolitan Detention Center) - The facility where Ghislaine Maxwell is housed as a pretrial detainee.
keyFacts: Judge Alison J. Nathan denied Ghislaine Maxwell's request to direct the MDC to stop flashlight checks during the night, finding the request factually unsubstantiated and legally unsupported.
The court ordered the MDC to consider whether sleep disruptions for pretrial detainees can be reduced and to ensure Maxwell is only subjected to necessary security protocols based on neutral factors.

The Government reported that MDC staff conduct flashlight checks of all inmates as standard procedure, with checks every 30 minutes for those in the Special Housing Unit and multiple checks per night for general population inmates.
Flashlights are pointed at the ceiling of the cell during checks to confirm the inmate is present, breathing, and not in distress, not directly into their eyes as claimed by defense.
The MDC determined that more frequent safety checks for Maxwell were necessary due to her being housed alone, the nature of the charges, and the high-profile nature of the case.
